svg:text.svg:tspan: I know what you’re thinking... what’s this got to do with GCSE English? The short answer — nothing at all.
If you’re looking for the Eduqas exam activities, they start on the next page. But if, like me, you appreciate
a good cup of tea, then take a five-minute break and learn how to make yourself the perfect cuppa.
For a follow these easy step-by-step instructions:
1)First, pour some into a and switch it . (Check it’s switched on at the wall too.)
2)Let the kettle . While you’re waiting, see what’s on TV later and check
your belly button for fluff. Oh, and put a in a .
3)Once the kettle has boiled, the water into the mug.
4) the tea bag about a bit with a spoon. the tea bag.
A good mug is an essential part of the tea drinking experience, but choosing the right
vessel for your tea can be tricky. Here’s a guide to choosing your mug:
Now this is important — once you’ve made your cuppa:
1)Have a quick rummage in the kitchen cupboards for a .
(Custard creams are best. Steer clear of any ginger biscuits — they’re .)
3)Sit back and enjoy your mug of tea. You’ve .
Phew — time for a brew I reckon...
It’s best to ignore what other people say about making tea and follow this method. Trust me, this is the most
definitive and effective method. If you don’t do it this way, you’ll have a shoddy drinking experience.
